case_vignette: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician because of fatigue and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months despite a good appetite. He takes no medications. He does not smoke or use illicit drugs. Physical examination shows hepatosplenomegaly and diffuse, nontender lymphadenopathy. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 11 g/dL and a leukocyte count of 16,000/mm3. A direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test is positive. A photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear is shown.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.

I've been feeling very tired and I've lost about 11 pounds in the last 6 months even though I've been eating well.

The case vignette does not mention any persistent fevers or night sweats.

Yes, I've noticed swelling in different parts of my body, it's not painful.

I am a 72-year-old man.
Do you have a history of smoking or exposure to chemicals or radiation?
No, I do not smoke and I haven't used any illicit drugs.
Do you have a family history of cancer or blood disorders?
The case vignette does not provide information about my family history.

The vignette doesn't mention any changes in my vision or frequent infections.

I'm not taking any medications.

The case vignette does not mention any changes in my bowel habits or blood in my stool or urine.
Have you had any recent blood work or medical tests done? If so, what were the results?
Yes, my blood work showed a hemoglobin concentration of 11 g/dL and a white blood cell count of 16,000/mm3. Also, the direct antiglobulin test, also known as the Coombs test, was positive.
Final Diagnosis: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia.
